court_response_anchor.surface_text: held against the appellants on two grounds, one that ignorance of law cannot be a sufficient cause,

holdings.text: The second proviso to s.15(2) of the Payment of Wages Act is in substance similar to s.5 of the Limitation Act, requiring sufficient cause that covers the whole period of delay.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that in dealing which the question of condoning delay under s. 5 of the Limitation Act the party has to satisfy the court that he had sufficient cause for not preferring the appeal or making the application within the prescribed time, and this has always been understood to mean that the explanation has to cover the whole of the period of delay Vide Ram Narain Joshi v. Parameswar Narain Mehta 1903 I.L.R. 30 Cal. 309 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso limits institution of application itself like s.5 Limitation Act; judicial consensus requires explanation for entire delay period per precedents such as Ram Narain Joshi.

holdings.text: Decisions such as Lingley v. Thomas Firth & Sons Ltd. and cases under Workmen's Compensation Act s.10 are distinguishable and their principles have no application to the second proviso to s.15(2) of the Payment of Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thus it would be clear that the decisions on which Mr. Phadke founds his argument were concerned with a statutory provision as to limitation which is essentially different from the provision made by the proviso with which we are concerned. The proviso with which we are concerned has prescribed the limitation of six months for the institution of the application itself, and so the principle laid down in Lingleys case  1921  1 K.B. 655, can have no application to the question which we have to decide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes based on structural differences in limitation provisions: notice/claim separate from proceedings in those cases, versus limitation on application filing here.

holdings.text: The authority's finding that appellants failed to show sufficient cause for delay after Ruby Mills decision on May 2, 1952, is a binding question of fact fatal to their condonation claim and overtime wages applications.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already noticed the authority has held against the appellants on two grounds... This latter conclusion is a finding on a question of fact and its propriety or validity could not have been challenged before the High Court and cannot be questioned before us in the present appeals... Therefore the finding recorded by the authority that the appellants have failed to establish sufficient cause for their inaction between May 2, 1952, and the respective dates on which they filed their present applications is fatal to their claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding unchallenged in High Court and not reviewable in SC; applies whole-period requirement to reject condonation.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed, with parties to bear their own costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeals fail and are dismissed. The respondent has fairly not pressed for his costs, and so we direct that the parties should bear their own costs in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from binding factual finding and legal interpretation of proviso requiring whole-delay explanation.
